Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Story: I stared at my phone, reading Mia’s message: “Let’s pick a night for our date! We finally have time.” I smiled, thinking about how we’d both been waiting for a week like this, free evenings stretching ahead of us. She deserved my full attention, a real night out, not just takeout and tired conversation. But as I started to reply, my work email pinged. The project manager’s subject line was urgent: “Need your estimates by tomorrow—client contract depends on it.” I knew the team was waiting on me, and any delay would push the whole project back. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of Mia’s anticipation and the pressure of my team’s expectations. I wanted to be the boyfriend who made her feel special, but I was also the engineer everyone was counting on. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I tried to figure out how to be both at once.
